Starting on Open Source

24 Jul 2017

In this blog post I’m going to highlight some steps that were helpful along the way.

After seeing other people talking about their journey into open source software, I decided to take my chances and created this PR during past week.

A friend of mine mentioned this First Timers Only medium post from Kent C. Dodds. After getting convinced that I was, too, capable of doing some contribution to the open source community, I started searching for other online resources that could help me to get started. Later on at the same day I found out the First Timers Only website that is an initiative of Kent and Scott Hanselman. They go straight to the point and list an awesome site that aggregates project that actively want help. It is http://up-for-grabs.net. Once at this website, you can filter projects by popular tags - like main language or platform - and start searching were exactly you would fit easily. As I read before, I tried to pick a project that I’d be comfortable with - and by comfortable I mean that I already have some knowledge of the language and the tooling that it’s used. Starting something new has it’s challenges already so I wasn’t looking to make things even more complicated. After some browsing, I decided to go with cdnjs project. They have a huge number of issues open (by the time that I write this, I can see almost 800 of them) and they also already took the initiative of labeling the issues for beginners like me. :) The issue that I picked consisted of adding a library to their repo. The cdnjs project has a good contributing document which was very helpful and really made a difference for me.

After I submitted the PR I got some requests from the project maintainers to fix stuff that I missed - like using source code from a development branch instead of a tag or release branch or not squashing commits as their contributing documentation suggested.

That’s it.

Here are some more references that were helpful in this process.

  • Get Involved
  • Up For Grabs
  • How to contribute on GitHub
  • Git Changing old commit message
  • Git Squashing commits
  • Starting with open source from Shubheksha
